item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
You can do this: 

if ( !is_user_logged_in() )
     auth_redirect();

item.title: Ticket #7001 (Admin SSL Support) updated
item.dc:creator: alexrabe
item.description: I used this method for tinymce buttons and also for files (ajax, flash upload) which are called direct. I have seen similar practice for other plugins. If is_used_logged_in() did the same job I can change this for me. Thanks

item.title: Ticket #7001 (Admin SSL Support) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: So, 2.6 has two cookies. "wordpress_logged_in" is a read-only cookie that is delivered for all pages. It indicates that the user is logged in and allows looking at some of that's users private data. is_user_logged_in() checks this cookie. "wordpress" is a read/write cookie that is delivered only for wp-admin/. It has the power to make changes. auth_redirect() checks this cookie. Since it is only delivered for wp-admin/, files in the plugins directory that directly load admin.php will not be authorized. This is a back compat break, which sucks, but it also prevents attacks that mess around with files in the plugins directory from getting at the auth cookie. If direct loading admin.php from the plugins directory is a common practice, I guess we'll have to set an auth cookie for the plugins directory.

item.title: Ticket #6492 (Guids No Longer Have Permalink Format) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
I think that the so-called replication problem with it basically means that if you do something like this: INSERT INTO whatever (guid) VALUES (UUID());

And have that whatever table replicating, then the slaves will get different UUIDs than the master. The UUID function call is replicated over to the slaves, making them generate new UUIDs. If, however, you pull out a UUID and then treat it as a string instead, it works fine.

Also, I think the ante should be upped to MySQL 4.1 anyway. But, it's entirely possible to create a UUID function in PHP, or just snag it from free code elsewhere, if the MySQL 4.0 support is such a big requirement.

item.title: Ticket #7193 (Patch for fixing most out of memory errors when importing) created
item.dc:creator: mark8barnes
item.description:
It's fairly common to run out of memory when importing. It seems a main reason for this is that the rewrite rules are flushed every time a post is created. On one of my blogs, this uses up over 1Mb of memory that you don't get back (it has 200 static pages and the /%post-name%/ permalink structure).

It seems to me that there's an easy fix for each of the importers. The fix should also save on processing time.

  1. Firstly, create a function that duplicates the _save_post_hook function and remove the rewrite commands from it.
  1. Then remove_action('save_post', '_save_post_hook', 5, 2) and add_action('save_post', 'custom_function', 5, 2).
  1. Perform the import.
  1. Reverse the remove/add actions.
  1. Flush the rewrite rules.

Perhaps a more elegant solution would be to provide a hook or variable that could be passed to _save_post_hook that would prevent the rewrite rules flushing. That way it saves having duplicate code in two functions.

item.title: Ticket #6492 (Guids No Longer Have Permalink Format) updated
item.dc:creator: AaronCampbell
item.description: Unfortunately, the ​WordPress Requirements support down to MySQL 4.0 which doesn't have UUID(), so there would be more code involved than that. Also, since it doesn't work with replication, I wonder what problems that would cause.

item.title: uuid.diff attached to Ticket #6492
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: UUID patch example

item.title: Ticket #6492 (Guids No Longer Have Permalink Format) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Yeah, sorry if that was unclear...

I just don't see the value in using the permalink for this if the permalink can change anyway. What's more, as has been shown, you can get conflicts when you do imports and such, if you are importing from your own older blog and so forth.

A UUID makes more sense. It's unique across the whole of space and time (in theory). It's shorter than most permalinks. And it's built in for just this sort of usage.

Quick and dirty example patch attached.

Closing as WONTFIX due to lack of evidence for demand, and the available and easily found plugin.

item.title: Ticket #4448 (Update theme files) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Yes, it is possible to create this error in some situations. The theme editor does an is_writable check before attempting to write the file, but is_writable is not reliable in all situations and it can return true even if the file is not accessible.

In theme-editor.php, this code: 

	if (is_writeable($real_file)) {
		$f = fopen($real_file, 'w+');
		fwrite($f, $newcontent);
		fclose($f);
		$location = "theme-editor.php?file=$file&theme=$theme&a=te";
	} else {
		$location = "theme-editor.php?file=$file&theme=$theme";
	}

...has no error checking on the fopen. $f needs to be compared to === FALSE before attempting to fwrite and fclose it.

item.title: Ticket #4388 (Configuration page for wp-cron jobs) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
The problem with this issues is that disabling the problematic plugins won't help. The damage has been done, the entries are in the cron jobs with no way to remove them.

While this has indeed been a big problem for some people, a few plugins have been made to deal with it since I created this ticket.

I refer people to WP-Crontrol: ​http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/wp-crontrol/

Still, I think that WP could potentially be made smarter here and possibly deal with this situation automatically. However, a plugin is fine for now.

item.title: Ticket #4388 (Configuration page for wp-cron jobs) closed
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description:
wontfix:

I think this should remain plugin territory.

Badly written plugins can cause all sorts of problems and I'm not sure we should change the interface, to add something most users won't understand, to help solve just one of these problems.

My first bit of advice to people experiencing problems with WordPress is usually to disable every plugin and see what happens.

item.title: Ticket #3604 (wp-admin Password Encryption via JavaScript) closed
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description:
wontfix:

I'm not sure that the public/private key bit is relevant. You need a secure means to transfer one of the keys to the other end point - that you're not likely to be using a public hotspot at the time of install isn't good enough.

As for Clipperz - I believe it only provides secure local storage of passwords, it doesn't secure the password in transit to a web application.

I believe that this ticket is asking for a challenge/response system implemented using Javascript/RSA. This'll be very complicated to get correct. It's planned that 2.6 will have better support for https protected admin pages. SSL is tried and tested and doesn't introduce code that we need to maintain.

Closing as WONTFIX. A working and tested plugin implementation would do much to persuade me otherwise.

item.title: Ticket #3568 (class-pop3.php does not always correctly read till end-of-mail on mail ...) closed
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description:
invalid:

fix22: I'm not sure I completely follow this - do you have an example of a mail that fails to be retrieved? I'll test that with the current code. The regular expression "\.\r\n" checks for the full stop that indicates the end of an SMTP message so I'm not entirely sure why that's not working for you (a message with a "." on a line should actually be represented by ".." and I'm pretty sure that if messages containing a . on a single line in their body were causing problems we'd see a much busier ticket).

I'll close this ticket as invalid until then. Please feel free to reopen.

item.title: Ticket #7192 (Password recovery key must not contain hash # character) created
item.dc:creator: mastermind
item.description:
On a site where I was registered, I tried to retrieve a new password. The activation URL was like:

​http://example.com/wp-login.php?action=rp&key=J#wi7fuQw8H

When calling the URL, the WP install told me the key was invalid -- obviously, because the hash and the part thereafter are not sent to the server, but are interpreted as anchor. Encoding the hash as %23 didn't help neither; I assume this is because the respective function does not urldecode() the key.

item.title: Ticket #7149 (prevent inadvertent output from included files) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
Yes, wraping it in an output buffer *would* prevent errors from occuring.

However, Its mearly preventing the displayment of an error which the user, a plugin, or a core file introduces, The error should be corrected, not worked around.

It would also break any sites which use the output buffer for things such as gziping the content AFAIK.

item.title: Ticket #7149 (prevent inadvertent output from included files) updated
item.dc:creator: mm6
item.description: Scratch the previous comment. It does take two newlines. Forgot about the one the editor adds, but it only takes one added intentionally.

item.title: Ticket #7149 (prevent inadvertent output from included files) updated
item.dc:creator: mm6
item.description: And a single newline after ?> in a theme's functions.php will break a lot of XML parsers, breaking feeds and XMLRPC responses for the site.

item.title: Ticket #7149 (prevent inadvertent output from included files) updated
item.dc:creator: mm6
item.description:
Something like this would automatically fix these types of problems in all present and future themes. Trying to proactively fix something which causes subtle breakage of major site functionality is not "inane and hackish".

Your solution is to rely on all theme authors and modifiers to do something that not a lot of people know about and seems wrong (people are used to closing tag-type things that they opened). The large majority of themes (including the default Wordpress theme) include closing ?>.

item.title: Ticket #7157 (Disable APP and XMLRPC publishing by default) updated
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description:
New patches:

  • Provide helpful error message when XML-RPC is not enabled. Now done as part of the authentication check.
  • Provide helpful error message when AtomPub is not enabled.
  • Enable XML-RPC and AtomPub when doing upgrades.
  • Remove check box for enabling XML-RPC & AtomPub during install.

The only XML-RPC functions that don't attempt to authenticate users are:

  • demo.sayHello
  • demo.addTwoNumbers
  • mt.supportedMethods (which seems pretty useless in light of system.listMethods)
  • mt.supportedTextFilters
  • mt.getTrackbackPings
  • pingback.ping
  • pingback.extensions.getPingbacks

Turned XML-RPC and AtomPub back on for upgrades to reduce the amount of surprised existing users will have.

item.title: Ticket #7190 (Category and tag archive pages should generate correct link rel for feeds) created
item.dc:creator: borismann
item.description:
Currently, if you go to a category archive page (eg. /categories/cat-name) the link rel in the header simply outputs the main blog feed. There is no way to tell -- including from view source -- that there are per category / tag feeds available.

This might just be a general enhancement to bloginfo(rss2_url) -- it could auto detect what page it is on and just "do the right thing" -- otherwise you end up having to manually edit the PHP of the header of themes to put logic in for this.

item.title: Ticket #7188 (wp_get_attachment_metadata doesn't check cache) closed
item.dc:creator: fshowalter
item.description:
invalid:

Realized I was wrong just as I hit submit.

item.title: Ticket #7188 (wp_get_attachment_metadata doesn't check cache) created
item.dc:creator: fshowalter
item.description:
wp_get_attachment_metadata always makes a database call for post information, even when one isn't necessary. The lines: 

$post_id = (int) $post_id;
if (!$post =& get_post( $post_id ) )
 return false;

Could, and probably should, be changed to: 

global $post;
$post_id = (int) $post_id;
if (empty($post) && !$post =& get_post( $post_id ) )
  return false;

For sites with many attachments per post, this could be significant gain.

item.title: Ticket #7185 (Trailing backslash shows first category) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description: Owner changed

item.title: Ticket #7187 (Category base not enforced) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description: Owner changed

item.title: Ticket #7187 (Category base not enforced) created
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description:
If the permalink structure begins with /%category%/ the category base is not enforced.

​http://www.example.com/category-base/category-slug ​http://www.example.com/category-base/category-slug/article-name

are the same as

​http://www.example.com/anything-else123/category-slug ​http://www.example.com/whatever/category-slug/article-name

item.title: Ticket #7185 (Trailing backslash shows first category) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description:
In fact, this happens with all illegal characters.

More examples of strings: ... " ; ş !

item.title: ozh_datei18n.patch attached to Ticket #7186
item.dc:creator: ozh

item.title: Ticket #7186 (Win32 / fresh install : date_i18n() outputs error) created
item.dc:creator: ozh
item.description:
Apache install on Win32, PHP 4.4.6 and fresh SVN install : the "Write" page spits several error messages:

Warning: date() [function.date]: Windows does not support dates prior to midnight (00:00:00), January 1, 1970 in E:\home\ozh\wordpress\wp-includes\functions.php on line 107

This is caused by date_i18n() when called by wp_post_revision_title():

  • $revision->post_modified_gmt is NULL
  • strtotime( $revision->post_modified_gmt . ' +0000' ) is -1 (5.1.0: strtotime now returns FALSE on failure, instead of -1)

Simple patch attached: make sure date_i18n() isnt given -1 as a timestamp argument.

Sidenote: I can swear I'll submit more tickets when this stupid wiki syntax is improved.

item.title: Ticket #4602 (Function for getting the clients IP address) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
I think the patch might need refreshing, I think theres been a change to a few ip sanitizations since then.

Moving the IP sanitisation to the get_ip function would be a good move too IMO, it would simplify moving to IPv6 support internally too.

item.title: Ticket #4602 (Function for getting the clients IP address) reopened
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Replying to pishmishy:

I'm not sure that this function will get included if it's only to be used in plugins (you may as well include the function in your plugin).

If there are places where such a function may be useful in the core then please let me know otherwise I'll close this as invalid.

You didn't check the patch, did you? It does use the function in the core, specifically in getting the IP address of the commenters.

Reopening.

item.title: Ticket #7185 (Trailing backslash shows first category) created
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description:
When using a permalink structure that begins with '/%category%/', adding a trailing backslash to the blog url shows the category page with the lowest id. Examples:

​http://www.example.com\ shows ​http://www.example.com/category/category-slug

It doesn't matter if the permalinks use a trailing slash or not.

item.title: Ticket #6742 (Add hook for translating English) updated
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description: I don't see the harm either, but not convinced I see the need =)

item.title: Ticket #6742 (Add hook for translating English) reopened
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
Sorry, seemed to be missed westi's response.

I'm talking about a plugin here, not my own personal blog.

However, I honestly can't remember what I was trying to do at the time. I think I was trying to use the default widgets page for managing the dashboard and didn't want to use an output buffer.

So yeah, reopening for feedback, but not hard set on wanting it as I can just use an output buffer to modify strings. Still though, having a pre-filter much like you can do with get_option() would be handy and I don't see any harm except maybe extra CPU cycles.

item.title: Ticket #6506 ("Rel" field when adding link) updated
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description: Woops sorry - wrong sort of links. With regards to the visual editor, I think you may be able to do this with a plugin. I'm not sure it's a field worth presenting to the user by default as most won't know what to do with it.

item.title: Ticket #6506 ("Rel" field when adding link) closed
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description:
invalid:

When adding a link use 'Link Relationship (XFN)' in the advanced options to set the 'rel' field.

Assuming that the default values for paging were given some thought as to their usefulness for the average user, and given that it'd be an optional feature for users...

... this sounds like something that should be implemented using a plugin I'm afraid.

item.title: Ticket #3764 (Selectable Output) closed
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description:
invalid:

I'm not sure that this is something that'll ever be implemented so closing. I'm pretty sure that everyone accepts that WordPress outputs XHTML and will continue to work this way.

If plugins/themes are producing invalid markup - chase the plugin/theme author :-)

item.title: Ticket #3775 (wp_die() does not have any formatting options which can break plugins ...) closed
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description:
worksforme:

Closing as worksforme due to lack of feedback. Please feel free to attach the test case in the future and reopen this ticket.

item.title: Ticket #3756 (Default theme (Kubrick) should default to no pingbacks or comments on pages) updated
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description: This issue doesn't appear to have been pushed much this year. I can see why some people might want pingbacks and comments disabled on pages but some of us also like to leave them enabled too. I'm going to recommend closing as wontfix.

item.title: Ticket #6663 (Wordpress source files do not correctly mark themselves as GPL) closed
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description:
wontfix:

I'm going to resolve this as invalid. Not even the Linux source marks each file explicitly as GPL licensed. I'm not a legal expert but I think that the license.txt is sufficient as the absence of a license when looking at a source file in isolation doesn't give you any distribution rights.

What may need to be fixed is something like the Akismet plugin which is distributed as a package in it's own right but doesn't include any license details in the source. This isn't the Akismet trac though :-)

item.title: Ticket #6318 (Birthday in User's Profile?) closed
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description:
invalid:

This is a good place to suggest ideas. Unfortunately I think this is something that's best done with a plugin if you require it. ​http://dev.wp-plugins.org/wiki/Userextra might be worth a look. You might also be interested in the efforts at ​http://buddypress.org/.

item.title: Ticket #6742 (Add hook for translating English) closed
item.dc:creator: pishmishy
item.description:
invalid:

Agreeing with Westi here. Nothing forces you not to use English in translation files. Since there's no response I'll presume that you've tried this method and been successful. Please let us know if there's problems with this approach though.

item.title: Ticket #7182 (feeds aren't canonical) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
Replying to markjaquith:

TODO: make sure that a high percentage of feed readers follow 301 redirects.

If they don't, would not exit()'ing after sending the 301 solve the problem? That way the feed content is still there for readers that don't know what to do with the 301.

item.title: Ticket #7128 (TinyMCE new paragraph inserts paragraph before current) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description: For those running WordPress 2.5, and Opera 9.5, You can use Help -> Check for updates in Opera to fetch the latest Browser.js file, Its got a fix included that should fix it. (June 25th browser js file)
